utterances: He and Al Gore were young.
They were attractive, one a governor, one a senator, both from the South.
But they brought the Democrats back to the center.
And I think it's interesting because I think President Obama is probably going to take the Democrats back to the left from what I see right now.
It's still too early to tell.
I thought he was going to be a centrist as well, but I'm not sure about that right now.
But I think the Republican Party is going definitely more towards the conservative side.
And I do think Specter's defection hurts us, regardless of what people may say about him.
And I think that we're losing moderates, and I think that's dangerous for us.
Let's see if we can get another caller in.
Darryl(ph) is with us.
Darryl, calling from Fort Lauderdale.
How are you?
Hello?
Darryl, are you there?
I'm afraid Darryl's cell phone is cutting in and out.
We apologize for that.
Hopefully he can try back again.
Let's see if we can go instead to Leo(ph).
Leo with us from Charlotte.
Hey.
How you all doing today?
Very well.
Thank you.
I've been a lifelong conservative Republican.
I'm 57 years old.

But I'm really concerned about the Republican Party in that the more they wrap themselves around the Christian Coalition and take the Christian values, the more they tend to fracture themselves and alienate themselves from the general public at large.
And really, I find this distasteful.
And I think that the conservative issue has gotten themselves confused with Christian issues, and that it's really reflecting poorly on the party itself.
I mean, when you're standing up there thumping the Bible, what do you think of in general?
What does the general public think of?
We're talking about the future of the Republican Party with David Frum and Sophia Nelson.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And David Frum, does Leo have a point?
Well, before I get to Leo, I have to say something to Sophia, which is I would like to invite her to join the group blog at New Majority.
I think she would find it a very congenial place.
And we would, you know, the nickels and pennies that you're getting from your blog, we can maybe go to dimes and nickels at ours.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And David, I reached out actually to Eric Cantor's folks this morning, so we're on the same page.
I'm going to see what I can do to be helpful.
Okay.
Terrific.
I want to go back to a couple of things that have been put on the table by all of the recent participants.
There is a tendency among conservatives to take a kind of what I would call a non-political view of politics.
It's about philosophy.
It's about principle.
It's about enunciation.
It's about self-expression.
It's about stating what's in your heart and inviting people to admire - it's not, it is about amassing majority to affect governmental change.
And what you also need to understand is how extraordinarily difficult change is to do and then to undo.
Conservatives who say things like, well, let Barack Obama win.
Let him have his innings and then we'll tidy up the mess.
We have never canceled the governmental program of any substance ever, ever.
It's never happened.
The board of tea tasters left over from the Spanish-American War is, I believe, still there, at least it was the last time I looked.
So the idea that Barack Obama is going to institute a major government health care program, which he has now the votes to do thanks to the Specter defection.
And we're going to come in 2013 to repeal it?
That's nonsense.
If it happens, it will happen forever.
If we - I am somebody who accepts the reality and the seriousness of the global warming or the climate change problem.

But if we can't - instead of a responsible, limited government carbon tax that is transparent and clear - if we get this massive system of subsidies and this cap-and-trade markup place and government direction of capital towards some energy industries rather than others, that's not going to be undone.
Did we ever undo agriculture subsidies?
Nobody likes them.
Everyone from every point of view agrees that they're deplorable and a mistake, and yet they're there, 70 years after Franklin Roosevelt put them in place.
So will the subsidiesâ€¦
(soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
So will the subsidies to wind turbines.
This is - it's too serious, it's too serious.
And yet, we have so many who say the important thing is self-expression, the important thing is capturing the party.
No, the important thing is governing the nation.
The important thing is - Sophia, go ahead.
What would I say is, I mean, yeah, David lays out a very good argument.
And I agree that the Republican Party, in order for it to go forward - I've always been of the school of thought that the problem wasn't with the message as much as the messengers.
Now, I know that if I say this to the black community, which I'm a part of I'm going to get hammered because what they'll say to me is, Sophia, the message is as whacked as the messengers.

But I disagree in that if you look at any polling data, for example, you take the black community, there was an article on CNN.com last night about - churchgoers, check this out, are more conservative on the issue of torture.
And it seems to be that - I call it interrogations, they call it torture.
But, for example, if you take those people who would regularly attend church, African-Americans, et cetera, they are much more conservative.
Black people in California defeated the homosexual marriage proposition, as we know.
So, black people, intrinsically, are more conservative.
They fit more with the Republican philosophy, always have.
But the problem is, we don't have people within the ranks of the Republican Party that look like, come out of the black community and are credible.
Just plucking up a black person off the street, which is what we've done for years in the GOP, and putting them out there and saying, go.
Now, you say you're black and you bring us black people, that doesn't work.
And so I'm looking for a revolutionary change within the Republican Party.
And I'm actually optimistic because I think that sometimes it's like being an alcoholic.
You got to hit rock bottom right before you can kind of come out of it and admit you got a problem.
I think that's where the GOP is.
We have to admit that we've got some problems and we need to deal with them.
Well, debate will continue on other days and other programs.
Thank you both for being with us today.
David Frum, who's editor at NewMajority.com and a regular contributor to American Public Media's Marketplace.
Thanks very much.
Thank you.
And Sophia Nelson, who joined us today from WETA, editor of Political Intersection blog.com.
Thanks as always, Sophia.
Up next on the Opinion Page, Retired Admiral Jerome Johnson argues that repealing don't ask, don't tell would inflict grave harm on the military.
TALK OF THE NATION, NPR News.
This is Talk of the Nation.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.

And whether you're surfing videos on YouTube or listening to this program when you should be making headway on that booming finance report, many of us have become quite adapt at rationalizing our doddling.
It's a wonder anything ever gets done.
Today, the latest on procrastination, if that's not a contradiction in terms.
Expert Timothy Pychyl joins us to talk about the inner mechanics of lollygagging and he'll bringing us up to speed on research.
We'll also hear from a self-professed structured procrastinator who claims procrastination is his best friend.
So tell us, is procrastination a positive or negative force in your life?
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And you can also weigh in on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later, to Chicago for closing arguments in the R.
Kelly trial, but first, procrastination, and let's go right to the phones.
Mark is calling, Mark from Portland, Oregon.
Hi Neal, thanks for taking my call.
Go ahead.
I was thinking about this as I heard it announced earlier.
I thought, the worst procrastinators in the world are probably the ones that resolve the problem at best, and that's artists.
Really?
Well, we're constantly thinking of doing new work, a new masterpiece.
And I can say, I call into Talk of the Nation many times.
I had the honor of talking to Simon (unintelligible) about a year and a half ago...
Oh, I remember that, yes.
About the power of art.

But I think as people see our works of art, and I guess I produced a few masterpieces, I don't want to refer to that myself but his relate to science, doing sketches of the eyepiece of a telescope as featured in the NASA web sites quite often.
I think = it's interesting that people see these.
They're impressed by them, they expect you to do another one.
They want to keep being entertained by artists so we're constantly pressed to produce new work.
And that's tough.
I mean, you're working against your own sense of ideas, I think.
But it's other people's expectations that, in a sense, weigh you down.
It is.
And it can pressure you to the point where you want to try to outdo your last work so you're kind of pressured to think of doing something better the next time.
So you tend to procrastinate.

You don't want to release something until you feel it's really great, and it's kind of a - there's an oxymoron taking place there, I think, between expectations of performance and trying to produce at the same time.
So you find yourself kind of stuck between a rock and a hard place.
And then you call the radio.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Hopefully someone's going to offer something as a resolution.
But you know, artists are known - all artists are really known to be performing artists, who are kind of entertainers, in a way, I think, in the public eye.
Well, let's see if we can get some answers for you, Mark.
